text: The long-term conspiracy theory that Barack Obama was not born in America came back to haunt Donald Trump in the first presidential debate at the University of Hofstra. For nearly two months in 2011, Trump fed a temporary presidential tender by raising doubts about Obama's birthplace. The case faded after Obama issued a long copy of his birth certificate showing that he was born in Hawaii, but Trump did not rest until two weeks ago. When the moderator asked Lester Holt Trump what took him so long, Trump tried to take the blame for moving the generator to two people from inside Clinton, Patty Solis Doyle, director of the 2008 Clinton Campaign, and Sydney Blumenthal, a friend and employee from time to time. "If you look at CNN this past week, Patty Solis Doyle was on Wolfe Blitzer saying this happened," said Trump. Blumenthal sent Maclatchi - a very respected reporter in Maclatchi - to Kenya to find out. They were pressing it too hard." Was Solis Doyle and Blumenthal -- two of Clinton's top lieutenants in 2008 -- severely compression of the generator? We'll take everyone in turn. What Doyle said on CNN Doyle was on CNN on September 16, 2016, and she was talking about an episode in 2007. Doyle described a volunteer coordinator in Iowa who sent e-mails promoting the conspiracy. I was asked during the interview if she meant the generator rumor. Doyle said she did. The Trump campaign indicated that this was a recognition that at least someone in the campaign had played a role. However, Doyle later explained that she was referring to a volunteer who had been dismissed from service for sending an e-mail on Obama's religion, not the place of birth. No matter what Doyle said in her interview, that's what happened. (Politi Fact written about here.) There is a rumor about Obama's religion that is very different from the rumors about where he was born.
